questions.text: Insulin independent absorption occurs in all except: (INICET NOV 2023)

questions.text: A patient presents to you with fever, jaundice, and malaise. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the serology reports given below? (NEET PG 2023) Anti-HBc (IgM): Positive HBsAg: Positive Anti-HBs: Negative Anti-HCV antibodies: Negative

questions.text: A doctor tells a 31-year-old woman, who is 20 weeks pregnant, that her baby has a developmental defect. She has come to you for a second opinion. The following US finding is seen. Identify the defect? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Anencephaly

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anencephaly is an open neural tube defect characterized by the absence of the cranial calvaria and prominent orbits, detectable by ultrasound as early as 10 to 11 weeks of gestation. It can be prevented with pre-conceptional folic acid supplementation.
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24 th edition pg 201, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8 th edition pg471
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24 th edition pg 201, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8 th edition pg471

questions.text: Identify the most common site of implantation in ectopic pregnancy: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Ectopic pregnancy refers to implantation occurring outside the endometrial cavity.
  • • Sites of implantation
  • • Uterine (.5%) such as cervical (1%), caesarean scar ectopic <1%)
  • • Management of tubal ectopic may be medical or surgical: medical management maybe considered if the patient is haemodynamically stable , foetal cardiac activity absent, beta HCG level less than 5000 , size of gestational sac less than 4 cm .
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Infundibulum: Accounts for 18% of ectopic pregnancies, but not the most common site.
  • • Option A. Infundibulum:
  • • Option C. Isthmus: Accounts for 25% of ectopic pregnancies, but not the most common site.
  • • Option C. Isthmus:
  • • Option D. Interstitial portion: Accounts for 2% of ectopic pregnancies, but not the most common site.
  • • Option D. Interstitial portion:
  • • Management of Tubal Ectopic Pregnancy:
  • • Management may be medical or surgical:
  • • Medical Management: Considered if the patient is hemodynamically stable, fetal cardiac activity is absent, beta HCG level is less than 5000, and the size of the gestational sac is less than 4 cm.
  • • Medical Management: Considered if the patient is hemodynamically stable, fetal cardiac activity is absent, beta HCG level is less than 5000, and the size of the gestational sac is less than 4 cm.
  • • Medical Management:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The ampulla of the fallopian tube is the most common site of implantation in ectopic pregnancy, accounting for 55% of cases.
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s Textbook of obstetrics page 207
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s Textbook of obstetrics page 207

questions.text: Identify the most common neurological complication following ligation of the Inferior mesenteric artery during abdominoperineal resection for rectal carcinoma? (NEET PG 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Parasympathetic - bladder dysfunction and retrograde ejaculation.

options.label: C
options.text: Sympathetic - retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction.

options.label: D
options.text: Sympathetic - Impotence and loss of cutaneous sensation in perineal region

questions.correct_answer: C. Sympathetic - retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Sympathetic - retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During abdominoperineal resection for rectal carcinoma, ligation of the inferior mesenteric artery may lead to sympathetic nerve damage, particularly the superior hypogastric plexus. This can result in neurological complications such as retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction.
  • ➤ During abdominoperineal resection for rectal carcinoma, ligation of the inferior mesenteric artery may lead to sympathetic nerve damage, particularly the superior hypogastric plexus.
  • ➤ This can result in neurological complications such as retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction.

questions.text: Identify the surgical step shown in the image given below: ( INICET May 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Capsulorrhexis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Capsulorrhexis is characterized by the creation of a controlled and continuous tear in the anterior capsule of the lens, which is essential for accessing and removing the lens material in cataract surgery. This method provides a clear opening without leaving jagged edges, which is crucial for the structural integrity of the remaining capsule necessary for IOL placement.
  • ➤ Capsulorrhexis

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with dragging pain in the abdomen. On examination, there is massive splenomegaly. Peripheral smear shows leukocytosis with increased myelocytes, metamyelocytes and basophils. Which of the following translocation is seen in this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) t (9:22)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The translocation t(9;22) is characteristic of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) and results in the formation of the Philadelphia chromosome, which produces the BCR-ABL fusion gene responsible for the disease's pathogenesis.

questions.text: A young male presented with palpitations and hence ECG was taken. ECG demonstrated narrow complex tachycardia and his BP was 70/40 mm of Hg. What is the next step in the management of this patient? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) is used to relieve pain. What is the mechanism behind it? ( INICET Nov 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Gate control theory

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) alleviates pain primarily through the gate control theory, which involves blocking pain signals at the spinal cord level by activating large-diameter afferent fibers.

questions.text: Which of the following lobes of the lung is affected when there is aspiration in supine position? (INICET MAY 2022)

questions.text: Inferior thyroid artery supply which of the following structure? 1. Thyroid 2. Parathyroid 3. Esophagus 4. Thymus
questions.explanation:
Ans.  A. 1, 2, 3 & 4

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The inferior thyroid artery is a branch of the thyrocervical trunk and arises from the subclavian artery. It runs upward in front of the vertebral column and enters the thyroid gland at its lower pole. Along its course, the inferior thyroid artery gives off several branches that supply the thyroid gland, parathyroid glands, larynx, trachea, esophagus, and the pharynx.
  • • Thyroid : The inferior thyroid artery primarily supplies blood to the thyroid gland . The gland requires a substantial blood supply due to its high metabolic activity, especially when it's actively producing thyroid hormones. The inferior thyroid artery enters the thyroid gland at its posterior aspect and supplies the majority of the gland, especially its inferior portion. Parathyroid : The parathyroid glands are small endocrine glands located on the posterior surface of the thyroid gland. There are usually four parathyroid glands: two superior and two inferior. The inferior parathyroid glands are typically supplied by the inferior thyroid artery. The blood supply to these glands is crucial because they produce parathyroid hormone (PTH), which plays a vital role in calcium homeostasis. Esophagus : The esophagus , especially its cervical portion, may receive some blood supply from the branches of the inferior thyroid artery. However, it's essential to note that the primary blood supply to the esophagus comes from the esophageal branches of various arteries along its length, such as the aorta and the left gastric artery. Thymus : While the inferior thyroid artery is not a primary source of blood supply for the thymus, there can be some anastomotic connections between the vessels supplying these structures in the anterior mediastinum. However, the primary blood supply to the thymus comes from the internal thoracic and anterior mediastinal branches.
  • • Thyroid : The inferior thyroid artery primarily supplies blood to the thyroid gland . The gland requires a substantial blood supply due to its high metabolic activity, especially when it's actively producing thyroid hormones. The inferior thyroid artery enters the thyroid gland at its posterior aspect and supplies the majority of the gland, especially its inferior portion.
  • • Thyroid
  • • thyroid gland
  • • Parathyroid : The parathyroid glands are small endocrine glands located on the posterior surface of the thyroid gland. There are usually four parathyroid glands: two superior and two inferior. The inferior parathyroid glands are typically supplied by the inferior thyroid artery. The blood supply to these glands is crucial because they produce parathyroid hormone (PTH), which plays a vital role in calcium homeostasis.
  • • Parathyroid
  • • inferior parathyroid glands
  • • Esophagus : The esophagus , especially its cervical portion, may receive some blood supply from the branches of the inferior thyroid artery. However, it's essential to note that the primary blood supply to the esophagus comes from the esophageal branches of various arteries along its length, such as the aorta and the left gastric artery.
  • • Esophagus
  • • esophagus
  • • Thymus : While the inferior thyroid artery is not a primary source of blood supply for the thymus, there can be some anastomotic connections between the vessels supplying these structures in the anterior mediastinum. However, the primary blood supply to the thymus comes from the internal thoracic and anterior mediastinal branches.
  • • Thymus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The thyroid gland receives its main arterial blood supply from the superior and inferior thyroid arteries. The inferior thyroid artery also supplies the parathyroid glands with blood. Additionally, its branches provide blood to the esophagus, larynx, trachea, thymus and pharynx.
  • ➤ Branches:
  • ➤ Branches:
  • ➤ Pharyngeal branches Ascending cervical artery Inferior artery Muscular branches
  • ➤ Pharyngeal branches
  • ➤ Ascending cervical artery
  • ➤ Inferior artery
  • ➤ Muscular branches
  • ➤ Thymic branches – originate from internal thoracic, inferior thyroid arteryand often superior thyroid arteries & supply the thymus.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with bare lymphocytic disease. In this patient, graft vs host reaction does not occur due to: (INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: C
options.text: MHC class II deficiency on lymphocytes

options.label: D
options.text: MHC class I deficiency on lymphocytes

questions.correct_answer: C. MHC class II deficiency on lymphocytes
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) MHC class II deficiency on lymphocytes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with Bare Lymphocyte Syndrome type 2 (BLS 2), the absence of MHC class II molecules on lymphocytes results in a lack of CD4+ T cells, preventing graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) from occurring.

questions.text: Which is the most common intraocular malignancy in adults? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Choroidal metastasis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The most common intraocular malignancy in adults is choroidal metastasis.
  • • Metastatic tumors to the eye, particularly to the choroid, are more common than primary intraocular malignancies. These metastases usually originate from primary cancers in other parts of the body, such as the breast or lung. The choroid is a vascular layer of the eye that provides a conducive environment for metastatic cells to thrive.
  • • The most common primary intraocular malignancy is choroidal melanoma. Choroidal melanoma is the most common primary intraocular cancer in adults, but overall, metastases are more prevalent.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Retinoblastoma : This is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in children , not adults.
  • • Option A. Retinoblastoma
  • • most common
  • • children
  • • Option B. Choroidal melanoma : While this is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in adults , it is less common than metastatic tumors overall.
  • • Option B. Choroidal melanoma
  • • most common primary intraocular malignancy
  • • adults
  • • Option C. Uveal melanoma : This term encompasses melanomas of the choroid, ciliary body, and iris.
  • • Option C. Uveal melanoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Most common intraocular malignancy in adults - Choroidal melanoma Most common primary intraorbital malignancy in adults -Capillary Hemangioma. Most common primary intraocular malignancy in children – Retinoblastoma Most common intraorbital malignancy in children – Rhabdomyosarcoma
  • ➤ Most common intraocular malignancy in adults - Choroidal melanoma
  • ➤ intraocular
  • ➤ adults -
  • ➤ Most common primary intraorbital malignancy in adults -Capillary Hemangioma.
  • ➤ intraorbital
  • ➤ adults
  • ➤ Most common primary intraocular malignancy in children – Retinoblastoma
  • ➤ primary intraocular
  • ➤ children
  • ➤ Most common intraorbital malignancy in children – Rhabdomyosarcoma
  • ➤ intraorbital
  • ➤ in children

questions.text: A chronic smoker was on nicotine replacement therapy and clonidine tablets for smoking de-addiction. He stopped taking clonidine tablets and now presents with a headache. What is the reason behind this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Rebound hypertension

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rebound hypertension is a critical condition that can occur when clonidine, an alpha-2 agonist, is suddenly discontinued. This results in a rapid increase in sympathetic activity, leading to symptoms such as headache due to a sudden spike in blood pressure.
  • ➤ Rebound hypertension

questions.text: Devices which are not used in colorimetric test? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) RBC pipette

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The tools shows is the Sahli's method for hemoglobin estimation, a type of colorimetric test.
  • • RBC pipette : This device is specifically designed for counting red blood cells and is marked with a red bead. It is not used in hemoglobin estimation via the colorimetric method. The RBC pipette plays no role in this test, which is why it is the correct answer for the device that is not used in this process.
  • • RBC pipette
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Comparator : This is used to compare the color intensity of the hemoglobin solution with standard color shades to estimate the hemoglobin concentration.
  • • Option B. Comparator
  • • Option C. Hemoglobinometer tube : A crucial component of the Sahli's hemoglobinometer, this tube is marked for measuring hemoglobin concentration in percentage and grams per deciliter.
  • • Option C. Hemoglobinometer tube
  • • Option D. N/10 HCl : This reagent is used to convert hemoglobin into acid hematin, which can then be measured using the colorimetric method.
  • • Option D. N/10 HCl

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The RBC pipette is not used in the Sahli's method of hemoglobin estimation, which employs a colorimetric test involving the hemoglobinometer tube, comparator, and N/10 HCl.
  • ➤ RBC pipette

questions.text: What is the recommended treatment for a 9-month-old baby with diarrhea, who is feeding adequately, thirsty, and exhibits skin that returns to normal after a pinch within 2 seconds? (NEET PG 2018)

questions.text: Imagine a scenario where a novel medication is introduced that significantly reduces mortality from a specific disease but does not actually cure the disease.   • ➤ PREVALENCE

  • ➤ Total current (Old + New) cases in a given population over.
  • ➤ Prevalence = Incidence × Mean duration of disease [P = I × d]
  • ➤ Prevalence describes the balance between incidence, mortality and recovery
  • ➤ INCIDENCE
  • ➤ INCIDENCE
  • ➤ Number of new cases occurring in a defined population over a specified period of time.
  • ➤ Number of new cases occurring in a defined population over a specified period of time.

options.label: D
options.text: Early signs include generalised constriction of isopters and barring of blind spot

questions.correct_answer: D. Early signs include generalised constriction of isopters and barring of blind spot
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Early signs include generalised constriction of isopters and barring of blind spot

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Perimetry is vital for early detection and monitoring of glaucoma. Generalized constriction of isopters and enlargement of the blind spot are key early signs that can indicate the presence of this eye condition.

questions.text: What is the approximate time interval between HIV infection & manifestation of AIDS? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. 10 years

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mean interval b/w infection to AIDS is due to prolonged latency period (~10- years).

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison/HIV/Chap 201
